p: Evidence has emerged on the human-to-human transmission of the severe acute respiratory coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) in health care and family settings ( 1). As the virus spreads mainly through droplets, sneezes and aerosols ( 1), there is a high risk of transmission of SARS-CoV-2 during dental procedures ( 2). Recently, it was found that SARS-CoV-2 could be detected in saliva specimens which may allow viral transmission even among patients without cough or other respiratory symptoms ( 3). This report provides important recommendations based on the best available current evidence as well as lessons ( 4â€“ 7) from Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS, 2003) and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS, 2012) epidemics for a safety dental care management during the current SARS-CoV-2 pandemic.
